document.docAuthor: Barahona-Segovia, Rodrigo M., Riera, Pamela, Pañinao-Monsálvez, Laura, Guzmán, Vicente Valdés & Henríquez-Piskulich, Patricia
document.masterDocTitle: Updating the knowledge of the flower flies (Diptera: Syrphidae) from Chile: Illustrated catalog, extinction risk and biological notes

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Updating the knowledge of the flower flies (Diptera: Syrphidae) from Chile: Illustrated catalog, extinction risk and biological notes

figureCitation.captionText: FIGURES 206–209. Victoriana melanorrhina (Philippi, 1865): (206) lateral view (photo by Rodrigo Barahona-Segovia). Scale bar = 1.2 mm and (207) dorsal view (photo by Patricia Henríquez). Scale bar = 1.5 mm. Victoriana lugubris (Philippi, 1865): (208) lateral view. Scale bar = 1.2 mm (photo by Rodrigo Barahona-Segovia) and (209) male visiting an Asteraceae, Cerro San Cristóbal, Santiago (photo by Francisco Carreño).

“ Corral , Chile ” (T, A, MNHNCL )
.

Chilean distribution. From Valparaíso to Los Lagos region ( Fig. 200 ).
Altitudinal range. From coastal to precordillera ecosystems ( 0–1,600 m .a.s.l.).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 206–209.
Victoriana melanorrhina ( Philippi, 1865 )
: (206) lateral view (photo by Rodrigo Barahona-Segovia). Scale bar = 1.2 mm and (207) dorsal view (photo by Patricia Henríquez). Scale bar = 1.5 mm.
Victoriana lugubris ( Philippi, 1865 )
: (208) lateral view. Scale bar = 1.2 mm (photo by Rodrigo Barahona-Segovia) and (209) male visiting an Asteraceae, Cerro San Cristóbal, Santiago (photo by Francisco Carreño).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Biology and notes.
Victoriana lugubris
has been observed in flowers of
Hypochaeris
sp. on the edge of native forests (Álvaro Zúñiga-Reinoso, CSP record), feeding on
Mitraria coccinea Cav.
(Gustavo Lezana, CSP record), Asteraceae flowers (Francisco Carreño, CSP record) or hovering in the middle of remaining fragments of native forest chosing flowers of
Sarmienta scandens (J.D. Brandis ex Molina) Pers.
(Rodrigo Barahona-Segovia pers. obs.).
Conservation status. LC; EOO = 236,119 km 2 , AOO = 68 km 2 , 15 subpopulations and 16 localities.
